instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hi to all you nice and smart people 

I just have one question 

I am working on one <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and I do not trust completely the brd and pdf I have on it .
Long story short it doesnt turn on and upon a close inspection under the scope I found that the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> has a lot of pins non soldered 
that is the closest explaination I have , pins 1 2 4 6 7 do not have any contact at all !!!!
According to the documents only pin 6 is unconnected , am I reading this wrong or ....
No liquid damage .
I was just moving this board from one chassie to another and it worked before but now dead ... <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.59v and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.41v i will continue to check the other rails.... it takes only 17 miliamperes on the supply ...
Thanks in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message: <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> is likely fine. Are you using a KNOWN GOOD OEM 85 watt Magsafe 2 charger? Tried with all peripherals disconnected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
"pins 1 2 4 6 7 do not have any contact at all"
Do you mean bad solders, or missing pads from PCB?

If board worked before, disconnect any cable in the new case.
Test the board alone, use just USB mouse to confirm activity.
If works, then connect the cables one by one, untill board doesn't start.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
HI John and thanks for your reply 
yes I have tried with 3 different original (dont use knock offs :) chargers and they are all 85w and same result .
It is driving me crazy since the client turned it on and it worked just nice . I just took it out and put it in the new chassie (english is not my strong side) and it is comletely dead grrrrrrrrrrrr
I did disconnect the battery before (I always do that ) and stone dead .... the board that was there before had restart issues and the client was tired of that and thats why he bought this one .
Well from full working board I have managed to get a completely dead one , great work ....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:

it is hard to explain but it seems like they never have been soldered at all to the board !!! I would take a photo if I just could get the shitty amscope mu300 to play ball with me , I have only a black screen ...
not my day
they look like brand new and no joints at all (the pins) 
the board is on the bench and nothing is connected at all .....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 0V. That is a problem. Post voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>. If 5 volts, troubleshoot the <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> issue. If 0 volts, post voltage for <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
Thanks John 

the <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR> is 5.03v  so I come to the troubleshooting of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> ... :) I am new to this so bare with me :) am I right that it is created by <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message: Ok so looks like <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> issue. Resistance to ground on that line? Measure in ohms mode not diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message: the resistance on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0.3 ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message: Ok so you have a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. Just making sure, the die on <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> is ok? You have a short for sure on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, so you will need to inject voltage into that line to find it. Start voltage low around 1 volt and slowly increase to 3.3 if necessary.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
It should be but .... now you will laugh .... as said I am new to this and I have a problem :) My power supply does not want to stay at 1v . I soldered the wires to inject voltage and set it to 1v but as soon as I start it it falls down to 0.14 v and stays there ....  no matter what I put on the voltage it falls down to 0.14v at once... at that voltage nothing gets hot .... it is a Korad KA3005D ... 
I did not enable the voltage protection , no protection is activated ... still 0.14v grrr

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
If there is a pure short to ground, board tries to sink more than 5A, even at 1C.
5A limit bench power supply doesn't help in this case.
Its protection is triggered and will not inject anything.
I recommend to get 20-40A for such case, like here
[url]https://www.ebay.es/itm/480W-power-supply-Adjustable-Current-limit-12V-24V-36V-48V-60V-80V-120V-220V-DC/264278771163?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=563854956982&_trksid=p2060353.m1438.l2649[/url]
20V/20A, or even 12V/40A.

Lift now L7560 and check which pin the short remains.
If is on <CAPACITOR>C7592</CAPACITOR>, then remove <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and check again.
BE AWARE, do NOT power up the board WITHOUT <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>; just check for short!
If still short on <CAPACITOR>C7592</CAPACITOR> side, then you need to inject voltage and find the culprit.
Remove CPU heatsink when you do that.

However, before inject voltage, check for short at L7430 and L7630.
If one is shorted to ground, at same time with L7560, dead CPU 99.99%...

threads.message:
wooow bad news for me ......lifted L7560 , short still remained and it was on the <CAPACITOR>C7592</CAPACITOR> side ...... lifted the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>.... short still remained ....
Before I inject voltage i checked the L7430 no short but the L7630 is shorted ... should I inject voltage at all or should I consider the cpu dead ? 
It was working perfectly when I got it .... this is a mystery for me ....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message: If it is shorted, it would be smart to inject voltage just start low around 1 volt. Many many components on the <CAPACITOR>C7592</CAPACITOR> side. If it's the PCH, it will be obvious.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
Which is the exact ohm value at L7630?
You've told to have same board with shutdown issue.
Then compare resistance to ground between both boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
Well now I have really done it !!!! 
I took out ANOTHER working 00138 board from a completely working computer and mounted it in the clients computer just to be ready in time ... and ..... it is DEAD too !!!!
So now I have 3 dead boards 00138 and it is definately something in the clients computer that is killing them , this time I connected everything except the battery so the battery is excluded 
from the suspects . Does any of you have some idea what it could be ???? 
I have to say that all pieces are working with the clients old board but it suddenly restarts from time to time and that was the reason I now have 3 dead boards all taking 17 miliampere and stone dead..
The things I reused are , the trackpad , the side board (the small board on the side ) the laudspeakers , and the fans .....
any ideas ....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> question about the <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>
threads.message:
None of them should cause such a fatal issue.
Did you test all boards on the desk, w/o any device connected?
Only need an USB mouse, connected to onboard port.

Check <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure to use original 85W Magsafe 2 charger!
